leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.20] r 10.20 Personal service required only in certain circumstances (cf SCR Part 9, rules 1 and 2; DCR Part 8, rule 3; LCR Part 7, rules 3 and 20)

leg:heading.title: Personal service required only in certain circumstances (cf SCR Part 9, rules 1 and 2; DCR Part 8, rule 3; LCR Part 7, rules 3 and 20)

p.text: Any document required or permitted to be served on a person in any proceedings may be personally served, but need not be personally served unless these rules so require or the court so orders.
[subr (1) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[19], effective 15 August 2005]
Except as otherwise provided by these rules:

any originating process, and any order for examination or garnishee order, in proceedings in the Supreme Court, the Industrial Relations Commission (including the Commission when constituted as the Industrial Court), the Land and Environment Court, the District Court or the Dust Diseases Tribunal must be personally served, and
any originating process in the Local Court must be served in one of the following ways:
it may be personally served on the defendant,

it may be left, addressed to the defendant, at the defendant’s business or residential address, with a person who is apparently of or above the age of 16 years and apparently employed or residing at that address,

if served by the Local Court, it may be sent by post, addressed to the defendant, to the defendant’s business or residential address in an envelope marked with a return address (being the address of the Local Court but not so identified), and
any order for examination, garnishee order or subpoena for attendance in proceedings in the Local Court must be served in one of the following ways:
it may be personally served on the person to whom it is directed,

it may be left, addressed to the person to whom it is directed, at that person’s business or residential address, with a person who is apparently of or above the age of 16 years and apparently employed or residing at that address,
and
any subpoena for production in proceedings in the District Court or the Local Court must be served in one of the following ways:
it may be served personally on the person to whom it is directed,

it may be left, addressed to the person to whom it is directed, at that person’s business or residential address, with a person who is apparently of or above the age of 16 years and apparently employed or residing at that address,

it may be sent by post, addressed to the person to whom it is directed, to the person’s business or residential address in an envelope marked with the return address of the party at whose request the subpoena was issued.
As to service by post, see section 76 of the Interpretation Act 1987.

[subr (2) am Act 22 of 2005 s 5 and Sch 3, effective 1 June 2005; Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[20]–[22], effective 15 August 2005; Amendment 21 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 7 March 2008 ; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009 ; Amendment 31 of 2009 Sch 1[3], effective 1 February 2010]
If an envelope, posted as referred to in subrule (2)(b)(iii), is returned to the court by the postal authority as having not been delivered to the addressee:
service of the document contained in the envelope is taken not to have been effected, and
any judgment given or entered on the basis of that service is to be set aside,
and the registrar must so advise the party by whom or on whose behalf it was posted.
[subr (3) subst Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[23], effective 15 August 2005]
Service of a subpoena in accordance with subrule (2)(c)(ii) or (d)(ii) or (iii) is taken to be personal service for the purposes of rule 33.5(1) .
[subr (4) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[24], effective 15 August 2005]
Unless an earlier date is proved, a defendant who enters an appearance is taken to have been personally served with the relevant originating process on the date on which appearance was entered.

level.toc-caption: [10.20.5] “Originating process” in the Supreme and District Courts

p.text: Legislation cited in [10.20.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.14, r 9.6(1).

heading.title: “Originating process” in the Supreme and District Courts

p.text: “Originating process” is defined in the Dictionary as meaning the statement of claim or summons by which proceedings have been commenced, and includes a statement of cross-claim and a cross-summons. Note that personal service of a cross-claim is not required where the cross-defendant is already an active party in the proceedings: see r 9.6(1) .

Personal service of originating process is an important step in ensuring that a party receives proper notice of proceedings and is part of the fundamental requirements of natural justice or due process. Only in exceptional circumstances (usually involving urgent applications for interlocutory preservation or restraining orders) or under the authority of specific statutory provisions can a defendant be deprived of the entitlement to receive notice of the commencement of proceedings: R v County of London Quarter Sessions Appeals Committee [1956] 1 QB 682 at 691 ; White v Weston [1968] 2 QB 647 at 660; [1968] 2 All ER 842 . However, substituted service may be permitted under r 10.14 .

level.toc-caption: [10.20.10] Other documents where personal service required

p.text: Legislation cited in [10.20.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 18.5, r 33.5, r 42.8.

heading.title: Other documents where personal service required

p.text: Apart from the specific instances mentioned in the rule itself, the following documents are required to be served personally under the rules:
A notice of motion is required to be served personally on a person who is not a party to the proceedings or who is a party, but not an active party: r 18.5 .

heading.title: Copy of a judgment before committal or sequestration

p.text: A sealed copy of the judgment must be served personally on the person against whom the orders is sought: see r 42.8 .

Subpoenas must be personally served on the addressee: see r 33.5 . However, r 10.20(2)(d) permits service by delivery for post in the case of subpoenas for production in proceedings in the District Court or the Local Court.

An irregularity in the form of the document that has been served does not invalidate service and can be cured by amendment: Brady v Barrow Steel Works Ltd [1965] 2 QB 182 ; Richard Crookes Constructions (Qld) Pty Ltd v Wendell [1990] 1 Qd R 392 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.21] r 10.21 How personal service effected generally (cf SCR Part 9, rule 3; DCR Part 8, rules 3 and 14; LCR Part 7, rules 3 and 14)

leg:heading.title: How personal service effected generally (cf SCR Part 9, rule 3; DCR Part 8, rules 3 and 14; LCR Part 7, rules 3 and 14)

p.text: Personal service of a document on a person is effected by leaving a copy of the document with the person or, if the person does not accept the copy, by putting the copy down in the person’s presence and telling the person the nature of the document.

If, by violence or threat of violence, a person attempting service is prevented from approaching another person for the purpose of delivering a document to the other person, the person attempting service may deliver the document to the other person by leaving it as near as practicable to that other person.
Service in accordance with subrule (2) is taken to constitute personal service.

level.toc-caption: [10.21.5] Personal service — acceptance by the person served

heading.title: Personal service — acceptance by the person served

p.text: Two modes of personal service are permitted by the rules. First, leaving a copy of the document with the person to be served; or second, if the copy document is not accepted, by putting it down in the person's presence and stating the nature of the document. A document may be left with the person to be served (ie, service within the meaning of the first mode) even if the person does not actually take physical possession of the document from the server: Ainsworth v Redd (1990) 19 NSWLR 78 at 85–7, 88 and 89 ; cf Kenneth Allison Ltd v AE Limehouse & Co [1992] 2 AC 105 at 113; [1991] 4 All ER 500 . Thus, where a document was taken by a person accompanying the party to whom it was tendered, and that party was later seen to be reading it, the document was to be regarded as having been left with the party and therefore as having been personally served: Ainsworth v Redd, above at 85–7, 88–90; Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd v Rostkier (VSC, Batt J, No 11029/92, 2 June 1994, unreported, BC9406148) (document tossed at the feet of the person served).

level.toc-caption: [10.21.10] Document not accepted by the person served

p.text: Legislation cited in [10.21.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 10.14(3).

heading.title: Document not accepted by the person served

p.text: Where it is shown that the person has not accepted the document then, in order to prove service, it is necessary to establish that there has been compliance with the second mode of service permitted by the rule. The document should obviously be left as near as possible to the person to be served: Graczyk v Graczyk [1955] ALR 1077 (pushing a document under a locked door held to constitute good service). Touching the person with the document is not required, but may be justified if it is necessary to attract the person's attention to the existence of the document: Rose v Kempthorne (1910) 103 LT 130. It has been held that leaving an envelope containing the document does not constitute service unless it can be shown that the envelope was opened and the contents inspected: Re A Debtor [1939] Ch 251; [1938] 4 All ER 92 . It is generally not sufficient merely to leave documents with a third party for delivery to the person intended to be served: Re A Debtor [1939] Ch 251; [1938] 4 All ER 92 . But if it can be shown that the contents of the document were in fact sufficiently brought to the attention of the person intended to be served, then service may either be regarded as having been properly effected (Pino v Prosser [1967] VR 835 ; Ditfort v Temby (1990) 26 FCR 72; 97 ALR 409 ); or service may be confirmed under r 10.14(3) : Johnsen v Duks [1963] NSWR 730 ; Irving v Carbines [1982] VR 861 at 869 ; R v Heron; Ex parte Mulder (1884) 10 VLR (L) 314 at 317 ; City of Camberwell v Reed [1954] VLR 653 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.22] r 10.22 Personal service on corporation (cf SCR Part 9, rule 3; DCR Part 8, rule 12; LCR Part 7, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Personal service on corporation (cf SCR Part 9, rule 3; DCR Part 8, rule 12; LCR Part 7, rule 12)

p.text: Personal service of a document on a corporation is effected:
by personally serving the document on a principal officer of the corporation, or
by serving the document on the corporation in any other manner in which service of such a document may, by law, be served on the corporation.
Legislation cited in [10.22.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 ss 109X, 601CX.

Specific provisions concerning the service of documents on companies are contained in the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) ss 109X and 601CX . A document may be served on a local company by leaving it at, or by sending it by post to, the registered office of the company. Service may also be effected by delivering a copy of the document personally to a director of the company who resides in Australia or its territories. Where a liquidator has been appointed, the document may be served on the company by leaving it at, or by sending it by post to, the last address of the office of the liquidator that has been lodged with the Australian Securities and Investment Commission: Corporations Act 2001 s 109X . As to service of documents on a registered foreign company, see Corporations Act 2001 s 601CX . However, these provisions are permissive only and if the fact is that the plaintiff knows that the process, though purportedly served in accordance with the statutory provisions, has not and could not come to the attention of the corporation, it will be an abuse of process to proceed to obtain default judgment: Deputy Cmr of Taxation v Abberwood Pty Ltd (1990) 19 NSWLR 530; 2 ACSR 91 . For provisions concerning service on other corporate bodies, see the Local Government Act 1993 s 727, Co-operatives Act 1992 ss 440 and 440A.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.23] r 10.23 Personal service on Crown Solicitor (cf SCR Part 9, rule 3; DCR Part 8, rule 7A)

leg:heading.title: Personal service on Crown Solicitor (cf SCR Part 9, rule 3; DCR Part 8, rule 7A)

p.text: For the purposes of section 6 of the Crown Proceedings Act 1988, personal service of a document on the Crown Solicitor may be duly effected by leaving the document at the office of the Crown Solicitor with a person who is apparently a member of the Crown Solicitor’s staff.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.24] r 10.24 Personal service on judicial officers (cf SCR Part 9, rules 7A and 7B)

leg:heading.title: Personal service on judicial officers (cf SCR Part 9, rules 7A and 7B)

p.text: In proceedings against a judicial officer, personal service of any document may be effected by leaving a copy of the document:
in the case of a judicial officer of the Supreme Court or District Court, at the office of the principal registrar of that Court, or
in any other case, at the office of the senior judicial officer of the court at which the decision or determination was made,
addressed, in either case, to the judicial officer on whom it is to be served.
In subrule (1), judicial officer includes an Assessor within the meaning of the Local Court Act 2007.
[r 10.24 am Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 5 October 2007 ; Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[2], effective 6 July 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.25] r 10.25 Personal service on inmate of correctional centre (cf DCR Part 8, rule 11; LCR Part 7, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Personal service on inmate of correctional centre (cf DCR Part 8, rule 11; LCR Part 7, rule 11)

p.text: Personal service of a document on an inmate (within the meaning of the Crimes (Administration of Sentences) Act 1999) is effected by leaving a copy of the document, at the correctional centre at which the inmate is held in custody, with the general manager of the correctional centre.
[subr (1) am Amendment 29 of 2009 Sch 1[8], effective 8 October 2009]

Personal service of a document on a detainee (within the meaning of the Children (Detention Centres) Act 1987) is effected by leaving a copy of the document, at the detention centre at which the detainee is held in custody, with the centre manager of the detention centre.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.26] r 10.26 Personal service on person who ″keeps house″ (cf DCR Part 8, rule 13; LCR Part 7, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Personal service on person who "keeps house" (cf DCR Part 8, rule 13; LCR Part 7, rule 13)

p.text: If a person keeps house (that is, remains in premises to which a person attempting service cannot lawfully or practicably obtain access), the person attempting service may serve the document on the person keeping house:
by doing one of the following:
placing the document in the mail-box for the premises,
affixing the document to an outer door of the premises,

if the person attempting service cannot lawfully or practicably obtain access to any such mail-box or door, affixing the document to some part of the premises, or to some fence or wall surrounding the premises, as near as practicable to the principal door or entrance to the premises, and
within 24 hours after doing so, by posting a notice to the premises, addressed to the person keeping house, informing the person of the fact that the document has been so placed or affixed.
Service in accordance with subrule (1) is taken to constitute personal service.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 10.27] r 10.27 Proof of identity (cf SCR Part 9, rule 4A; DCR Part 8, rule 17; LCR Part 7, rule 17)

leg:heading.title: Proof of identity (cf SCR Part 9, rule 4A; DCR Part 8, rule 17; LCR Part 7, rule 17)

p.text: For the purposes of proof of service, evidence of a statement by a person of his or her identity or of his or her holding some office is evidence of his or her identity or that he or she holds that office, as the case may be.
In the absence of this rule such a statement would not be admissible in evidence: see Re Williams (1965) 7 FLR 101 .
